DOCNAME: CASE OF JEHOVAH'S WITNESSES OF MOSCOW AND OTHERS v. RUSSIA
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 9 read in the light of Art. 11;Violation of Art. 11 read in the light of Art. 9;Violation of Art. 6-1;Remainder inadmissible;Non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Dean Spielmann;George Nicolaou;Khanlar Hajiyev;Sverre Erik Jebens
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first applicant is the religious community of GPE 's Witnesses of GPE ( “ the applicant community ” ) established in DATE . The other applicants are members of that community . All of them live in GPE .
CARDINAL . The second applicant , PERSON PERSON , was born in DATE . He has been with the Jehovah 's Witnesses since DATE and is a community elder .
CARDINAL . The third applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE . He has been a member of the applicant community since DATE .

CARDINAL . The fourth applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE . He was twice convicted in NORP times – in DATE and DATE – for disseminating GPE 's Witnesses ' religious literature and officially rehabilitated in DATE as a victim of religious persecution .
CARDINAL . The fifth applicant , Mr PERSON , was born in DATE . He is a third - generation GPE 's Witness whose grandparents were exiled to LOC in DATE under an order deporting GPE 's Witnesses .
CARDINAL . Jehovah 's Witnesses have been present in GPE since DATE . They were banned soon after the Russian Revolution in DATE and persecuted in GPE .
CARDINAL . After LAW was enacted in DATE , on DATE the ORG of Justice registered the charter of ORG of GPE 's Witnesses in the GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of the NORP Federation registered the charter of ORG of GPE 's Witnesses .

CARDINAL . The applicant community , which is the GPE branch of the GPE 's Witnesses , obtained legal - entity status on DATE from ORG . According to its charter , the purpose of the applicant community was “ joint profession and dissemination of [ their ] faith and carrying on religious activity to proclaim the name of God the NORP ” .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE ORG from ORG ( “ the ORG ” ) , a non - governmental organisation aligned with ORG , filed a complaint against the members of the applicant community 's management with the LOC prosecutor 's office in GPE . It alleged in particular that GPE 's Witnesses burdened their followers with exorbitant membership dues that put their families in a financially precarious situation and that they incited hatred toward “ traditional ” religions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor 's office refused to institute a criminal investigation , finding no breaches of the community 's registered charter , the LAW or other laws . It was also noted that no complaints from private persons or legal entities concerning the activity of the applicant community had been filed .

CARDINAL . In DATE the ORG complained again and the inquiry into the same allegations was reopened . On DATE the prosecutor of LOC of GPE discontinued the investigation . Having heard several GPE 's Witnesses and completed a study of their literature , the prosecutor found that the applicant community did not cause any harm to the health of citizens or their rights and did not incite citizens to refuse to fulfil their civil duties or commit disorderly acts .

CARDINAL . Following a third complaint by ORG , the prosecutor in charge of supervising compliance with laws on inter - ethnic relations in ORG ordered the case to be reopened . On DATE an investigator with the prosecutor 's office of LOC of GPE again discontinued the investigation . She scrutinised in detail ORG allegations concerning the death of a Jehovah 's Witness who had refused a blood transfusion and accusations about alienation of family members resulting from their involvement in the religious activity of the applicant community . The investigator established that no harm allegedly caused by the management of the applicant community to other persons could be proven .

CARDINAL . Following a fourth complaint lodged by ORG , the investigation was reopened on DATE . The complaint was based on the same allegations as the previous ones . On DATE the same investigator discontinued the proceedings for the same reasons as those set out in her earlier decision . In particular , she pointed out that “ ORG statements are based upon their active hostility towards this particular religious organisation , whose members they [ the ORG ] deny the mere possibility of exercising their constitutional rights because of their religious beliefs ” .
CARDINAL . The ORG requested a new investigation for the fifth time . The GPE prosecutor 's office reopened the case and assigned it to another investigator on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the new investigator , in charge of particularly important cases in LOC of GPE , terminated the criminal proceedings . Her findings in respect of substantially the same allegations were different , however . She found that GPE 's Witnesses alienated their followers from their families , intimidated believers and controlled their mind , as well as inciting them to civil disobedience and religious discord . The investigator pointed out that the community acted in breach of NORP and international laws , but that no criminal offence could be established . Accordingly , she discontinued the criminal case but recommended that the prosecutor of LOC of GPE lodge a civil action for the applicant community to be dissolved and its activity banned .

CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor of GPE of GPE filed a civil action for the applicant community to be dissolved and its activity banned . The prosecutor 's charges against the applicant community were : ( i ) incitement to religious discord ; ( ii ) coercion into destroying the family ; ( iii ) encouragement of suicide or refusal on religious grounds of medical assistance to persons in life- or healththreatening conditions ; ( iv ) infringement of rights and freedoms of citizens ; and ( v ) luring teenagers and minors into the religious organisation .

CARDINAL . On DATE hearings before ORG of GPE began . The presiding judge admitted several new witnesses for the prosecution and allowed ORG to take part in the proceedings as a third party on the ground that it “ defends the rights of citizens ” , overruling an objection by the defence .
CARDINAL . On DATE the hearing was adjourned to DATE because the prosecutor was not ready .
CARDINAL . On DATE the prosecutor filed a supplementary action based on the same allegations and corroborated by references to quotations from the religious literature of GPE 's Witnesses .

CARDINAL . On DATE the proceedings resumed . The judge reversed her previous decision and , on a request by the defence , removed the ORG as third party in the case . The court proceeded to hear witnesses and experts .

CARDINAL . On DATE the court stayed the proceedings . The judge found that contradictions between the expert opinions submitted by the parties could not be resolved and ordered a new expert study of the applicant community 's religious beliefs . The court appointed CARDINAL experts – CARDINAL in religious studies , CARDINAL in linguistics and CARDINAL in psychology – and asked them whether the literature or materials of GPE 's Witnesses contained indications of incitement to religious discord , coercion into destroying the family or infringements of the rights and freedoms of others . The source material for the study included CARDINAL volumes of evidence in the civil case , literature and documents of GPE 's Witnesses , and the PERSON translation of the Bible .
CARDINAL . On DATE the CARDINAL - expert composite study was completed . On DATE the proceedings resumed and on DATE the ORG gave judgment .

CARDINAL . The Golovinskiy District Court heard TIME witnesses and experts and examined religious literature and documents . It scrutinised the experts ' report and took their oral testimony . A CARDINAL - page report by CARDINAL experts endorsed the prosecutor 's allegations , while the fifth expert dissented in a refutation of CARDINAL pages . The court noted that he was the only expert who had ever observed “ how GPE 's Witnesses carry out their preaching work in different countries ” , while the CARDINAL other experts “ confirmed that they did not examine anyone belonging to the indicated group [ Jehovah 's Witnesses or potential members of GPE 's Witnesses ] ” . As to the CARDINAL experts ' conclusions , the court also stated :

“ However , not one of the experts , including ... [ the ] psychologist , could explain to the court on the basis of what objective information or research they came to this conclusion regarding the influence of the literature of GPE 's Witnesses on people 's perceptions .

It is simply the experts ' appraisal of this particular religious organisation and is not supported by any actual facts showing incitement to religious discord , infringements of the personality and rights and freedoms of citizens , etc . ”

CARDINAL . ORG also referred to the conclusions of an expert examination of DATE performed by ORG at ORG . The examination , which was carried out at the request of ORG for the purpose of granting re - registration to ORG of the GPE 's Witnesses in GPE , found , with certain minor reservations concerning blood transfusion , that GPE 's Witnesses ' teachings inflicted no harm on citizens . ORG also had regard to the fact that in DATE over CARDINAL religious entities of ORG had obtained ORG registration in other NORP regions .

CARDINAL . ORG assessed the allegations advanced by the prosecutor and found that none of them had been based on any objectively verifiable facts . The court 's examination of testimony by the prosecutor 's witnesses who spoke in support of the allegation of coercion into destroying the family established that “ the testimonies simply show the stand relatives take when a member of their family becomes a GPE 's Witness and when it is unacceptable from the relatives ' standpoint ” .
CARDINAL . ORG determined that the other allegations were likewise unfounded :

“ Facts indicating deliberate incitement to religious discord , discrimination , hostility or violence , coercion into destroying the family , infringements of the personality and rights and freedoms of citizens ... were not adduced by the prosecutor or established by the court ...

... [ T]he court came to the conclusion that there is no basis for the dissolution and banning of the activity of the religious community of GPE 's Witnesses in GPE , since it has not been established that this community in GPE violates LAW or NORP laws , incites religious discord , coerces members into destroying the family , infringes the personality or rights or freedoms of citizens , encourages [ others ] to commit suicide or to refuse medical care for individuals who are in a life- or health - threatening condition for religious reasons . ”

CARDINAL . On an appeal by the prosecutor , on CARDINAL DATE ORG quashed the judgment of DATE and remitted the claim for a fresh examination by a different bench . ORG held that the ORG the existing expert opinions .

CARDINAL . On DATE a new LAW ( “ LAW ” ) entered into force . It required all religious associations that had previously been granted legal - entity status to bring their articles of association into conformity with the LAW and obtain re - registration from the competent ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE re - registered ORG of Jehovah 's Witnesses in GPE as a centralised religious organisation .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first application for re - registration of the applicant community was lodged with ORG . On DATE the GPE ORG refused to examine the application on the ground that some documents were missing , without specifying which documents these were .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE a second and third application for re - registration were filed , both of which were rejected by ORG on the same ground .

CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant , PERSON , sent a written enquiry to ORG asking which documents were missing . On DATE he brought an action against ORG before ORG of GPE , seeking a court order to oblige ORG to consider the third application . The court set a hearing date for DATE and requested ORG to provide a response by DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the deputy head of ORG informed the applicant community that it had failed to submit the original charter and registration certificate of DATE . He also informed the applicants that he was under no legal obligation to specify the missing documents .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicants filed a fourth application , which included the original charter and registration certificate . On DATE ORG issued the first formal refusal of re - registration . It referred to two allegedly incorrect wordings in the submitted documents : the GPE community had “ adopted ” , rather than “ approved ” its charter and the organisation had indicated its “ legal address ” only , but no “ location ” .

CARDINAL . On DATE the fifth application was filed , in which the CARDINAL required wordings were used . This was the last application because on DATE the time - limit for submitting applications for re - registration expired .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE ORG issued the second formal refusal of re - registration , in respect of the fifth application . It based its decision on the fact that the proceedings to have the applicant community dissolved and its activity banned were pending before ORG of GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the fifth applicant , PERSON , as an individual and founding member of the GPE community , filed a complaint with ORG of GPE against ORG first refusal of DATE . The court stayed the proceedings pending a decision of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the third applicant , PERSON , filed a complaint with ORG of GPE against ORG second refusal of CARDINAL DATE . The court asked for official information from ORG about the proceedings to dissolve the applicant community .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG of GPE dismissed the fifth applicant 's complaints , finding that the refusal of re - registration restricted only the rights of the GPE community , and not those of the fifth applicant himself . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment on appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the third applicant 's claim . The court held that , pursuant to section QUANTITY of LAW , re - registration could not be granted to organisations that might be liquidated or banned pursuant to section CARDINAL of LAW . The court added that the third applicant 's religious rights were not restricted by the refusal , which had only entailed legal consequences for the GPE community as a legal entity . On DATE ORG upheld the judgment on appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Presnenskiy District Court of GPE allowed the action in part . The court found that ORG had wrongly requested the original documents , copies of which had been available on file . It held that ORG reference to ongoing proceedings before ORG was inadmissible because it had first invoked this argument before the court and had never referred to it as a ground for its earlier refusals . The court declared ORG refusals unlawful but did not order re - registration of the applicant community on the ground that new application forms for religious organisations had been introduced and that the applicant community had to submit a fresh application for registration .

DATE . On an appeal by the applicant community , on DATE ORG upheld the decision of DATE . It decided that the application for registration could not be processed , not only because of the newly introduced application forms , but also with regard to the ongoing proceedings in ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE a new round of proceedings began in ORG under a new presiding judge . On DATE the hearing was adjourned .

CARDINAL . Following the adjournment , the community of GPE 's Witnesses in GPE collected CARDINAL signatures on a petition to protest against the prosecutor 's claim that she was protecting the rights of the community members . Copies of the petition were sent to ORG , the President , and ORG .

CARDINAL . On an unspecified date in DATE ORG ordered a new composite psycho - linguistic expert study of the applicant community 's literature and teachings . The proceedings were stayed pending its completion .
CARDINAL . On DATE the composite study was completed and its findings made available to the court .
CARDINAL . Following several oral hearings , on DATE the ORG of GPE decided to uphold the prosecution 's claim , to dissolve the applicant community and to impose a permanent ban on its activities .

CARDINAL . ORG found the applicant community responsible for luring minors into religious associations against their will and without the consent of their parents ( section QUANTITY of LAW ) and for coercing persons into destroying the family , infringing the personality , rights and freedoms of citizens ; inflicting harm on the health of citizens ; encouraging suicide or refusing on religious grounds medical assistance to persons in life- or health - threatening conditions ; and inciting citizens to refuse to fulfil their civil duties ( section LAW ) . However , the court found the applicant community not liable for extremist activity in the form of inciting religious discord with calls for violent acts ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . Likewise , it found unproven the allegation that the applicant community had collected contributions from its members for its benefit .

CARDINAL . Regarding the allegation of “ coercion into destroying the family , ” ORG relied on the statements by CARDINAL family members of GPE 's Witnesses DATE of which were members of ORG – who had been unhappy about their relatives ' abidance by the religious norms , their active involvement in the applicant community and their estrangement from non - religious family members . Thus , one husband had blamed the applicant community for the collapse of his family life , claiming that since “ his wife [ had ] joined ORG , she fulfil[led ] all their orders , [ he ] c[ould ] not discuss anything with her , or even watch TV with her because of her comments on everybody , including the leadership of the country and the ORG ” . Other witnesses complained that their adult children or , in CARDINAL case , the daughter - in - law had spent less time caring for elderly relatives because they had been constantly busy within the community . ORG further relied on the majority opinion of the expert study of DATE which determined that “ the texts of NORP 's Witnesses do not contain direct coercion into destroying the family but apply and propose for application direct psychological pressure which risks causing the destruction of families ” . Assessing the opinion by the dissenting expert and the findings of the new study of DATE , which found no coercion into destroying the family , ORG considered that these experts had limited the scope of their inquiry to publicly available literature of GPE 's Witnesses and had not analysed the “ actual activity of the GPE community ” or implementation of the religious commandments and recommendations “ in real life ” and their influence on family relations . ORG rejected statements by the witnesses for the defence who had GPE 's Witnesses in their families and the conclusions of a sociological study of CARDINAL community members , randomly selected , conducted by ORG at ORG on the ground that it had been based on the lists of respondents supplied by the community itself and failed to “ report a single instance of an internal family confrontation which objectively existed ” .

CARDINAL . As to the charge of infringement of the personality , rights and freedoms of citizens , ORG firstly found a violation of the right to privacy in that the applicant community determined the place and nature of work of its members , recommended that they engage in part - time employment so as to have time for preaching , prohibited them from celebrating holidays or birthdays , and required them to preach door to door , thus also invading other people 's privacy . As evidence of attempts to interfere with other people 's private life , ORG referred to the criminal conviction of a PERSON for beating a female community member who had offered religious literature to his wife at their home . Moreover , in ORG view , the applicant community violated its members ' right to a free choice of occupation as it recommended that they engage in part - time employment and provided applications for voluntary service at GPE , the community centre near GPE , where they only received a DATE living allowance and no salary .

CARDINAL . ORG found a violation of the constitutional guarantee of equality between parents in relation to the upbringing and education of children ( LAW ) because some parents involved their children in the religious activity of the applicant community without the permission of the other parent , a non - member of the community . It relied on the fact that there were pending custody disputes between parents in GPE courts where religious education had been in issue . It noted that where a Witness parent had been represented in the custody dispute by a community - retained lawyer , this amounted to “ a manifestation of interest in the outcome of the cases of the community itself and an interference with the family and private affairs of its members ” . ORG also relied on the opinions of CARDINAL psychiatrist witnesses for the prosecution who stated that “ the literal following of the Bible principles , as practised by GPE 's Witnesses , restricted the person 's independent thinking ... and arrested psychological development ” . In their view , a child who did not celebrate holidays would become “ a social outcast ” and the community 's teachings “ hindered the development of patriotic feelings and love for LOC .

CARDINAL . ORG found that the applicant community violated the right to freedom to choose one 's religion by resorting to active proselytising and “ mind control ” . According to the prosecution experts , GPE 's Witnesses were set apart from traditional religions because of the “ theocratic hierarchy of the community ” , “ their striving to integrate families into the life of a totalitarian non - secular collective ” and “ military - like discipline in domestic life ” . ORG accepted the opinions of the prosecution experts and rejected the contrary conclusion in the expert study that the defence expert psychiatrist had conducted of CARDINAL community members on the grounds that “ participants had been selected from lists supplied by the organisations ” and that the study “ only concerned the community members whereas their relatives had not been examined ” . ORG also considered that the petitions signed by the community members in its support had been “ evidence of the pressure that the community exercised on its members ” .

CARDINAL . Ruling on the charge of “ encouragement of suicide or the refusal of medical assistance on religious grounds ” , ORG found that under the influence of the applicant community its members had refused transfusions of blood and/or blood components even in difficult or lifethreatening circumstances . That finding was based on the following evidence : the prohibition on blood transfusion contained in the literature of the applicant community , the “ No Blood ” card distributed within the community for the benefit of its members , testimonies by community members who confirmed carrying such cards , the existence of ORG with the applicant community , and stories of patients who had refused a blood transfusion on religious grounds and whose refusal had been noted in their medical records . ORG also had regard to a letter from ORG that listed a number of instances in which patients had refused blood transfusions for themselves and , in CARDINAL case , in respect of a newborn child . Even though the medical outcome of those cases was not specified , ORG held that the proven fact of damage to the health of CARDINAL individual was a sufficient ground for terminating the activities of the GPE community . It further noted the opinions of medical experts who clarified that bloodless surgery was a prospective trend in medicine but that in case of certain diseases the transfusion of blood or its components was still indispensable . Finally , in ORG view , the “ No Blood ” card contravened the patient 's right to take medical decisions for himself by delegating that right – in the eventuality of his being unconscious – to his fellow believers .

CARDINAL . As to harming the health of citizens , ORG found that , in addition to the prohibition on blood transfusion , the activities of the applicant community had had a “ negative influence on the mental state and mental health of the followers ” . This assessment rested on opinions of PERSON family members who testified that they had seen “ sudden and negatives changes of personality ” in their relatives who had joined the applicant community and that many participants at religious meetings of GPE 's Witnesses had “ cried ” and had complained thereafter “ about colossal emotional exhaustion ” .

CARDINAL . As to luring minors into the religious association , ORG found , on the basis of statements by CARDINAL non - Witness parents , that where a Witness parent involved the child in the activities of the applicant community , there was an encroachment on the child 's freedom of conscience and the joint right of parents to participate in the child 's upbringing .

CARDINAL . Finally , ORG found that the applicant community 's literature incited citizens to “ refuse to fulfil their civil duties . ” This included refusal to serve in the army and to perform alternative service and promotion of “ a disrespectful attitude towards ORG emblems DATE the flag and the national anthem ” , as well as a prohibition on celebrating State holidays .

CARDINAL . ORG held that the interference with the applicant community 's rights was justified , prescribed by law and pursued a legitimate aim because the applicant community had “ violated rights and freedoms of citizens , and its activity led to the destruction of families , encroachments on the fundamental rights and freedoms of citizens and calls to refuse to perform duties to society ... Taking into account that the [ applicant ] community violated constitutional rights and freedoms of citizens , the contemplated restriction on its rights and termination of its activity is justified and proportionate to the constitutionally significant aims ” .
CARDINAL . The applicant community was ordered to bear the costs of the expert studies of DATE and CARDINAL DATE and to pay costs of MONEY to the ORG .

CARDINAL . The applicant community appealed , claiming , in particular , that the interference with its right to freedom of religion was not justified from the standpoint of ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention . It also invoked Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE and DATE of the Convention .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicants ' appeal in a summary fashion and upheld the judgment of ORG , endorsing its reasons .

DATE . The “ No Blood ” card referred to in the proceedings is a pre - printed foldable card that bears the words “ No Blood ” in capital letters on the front page and empty fields to be filled out concerning the person(s ) to be contacted in case of emergency and the holder 's allergies , diseases and medicine(s ) . The text inside the card reads as follows :
“ MEDICAL DIRECTIVE / RELEASE FROM LIABILITY
I , [ name ] , have filled out this directive as an official statement of my will . The instructions contained therein reflect my firm and conscious decision .

I direct that under no circumstances – even if doctors consider it necessary to save my life or health – shall any blood transfusion be performed on me ... I consent to the use of blood substitutes , hemodiluting solutions ... or bloodless methods of treatment .

By this legal directive I exercise my right to consent to medical treatment or refuse it in accordance with my principles and convictions . I am a GPE 's Witness and issue this directive in pursuance of the Biblical precepts ...

I release doctors , anaesthetists , hospital and medical personnel from liability for any consequences of my refusal of blood provided that I have been given full alternative qualified medical assistance .
Should I be unconscious , the person listed on the reverse side of the card [ emergency contacts ] may represent me before others , acting in accordance with this directive .
[ Date , signature , address , phone number , and signatures of CARDINAL witnesses ] . ”

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL guarantees freedom of religion , including the right to profess either alone or in community with others any religion or to profess no religion at all , to freely choose , have and share religious and other beliefs and manifest them in practice .
CARDINAL . DATE provides that everyone shall have the right to freedom of association .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL establishes that maternity , childhood and the family shall be protected by the ORG . The parents have equal rights and obligations with regard to providing care for children and their upbringing .
CARDINAL . On DATE LAW ( no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE – “ LAW ” ) entered into force .

CARDINAL . LAW prohibits the involvement of minors in religious associations , as well as the religious education of minors against their will and without the consent of their parents or guardians ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The founding documents of religious organisations that had been established before LAW were to be amended to conform to the LAW and submitted for re - registration . Until so amended , the founding documents remained operative in the part which did not contradict the terms of the LAW ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) . Re - registration of religious organisations was to be completed by DATE ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL , with subsequent amendments ) .
CARDINAL . NORP The list of documents required for ( re-)registration was set out in LAW § CARDINAL and read as follows :
“ — application for registration ;
— list of founders of the religious organisation indicating their nationality , place of residence and dates of birth ;
— charter ( articles of association ) of the religious organisation ;
— TIME of the constituent assembly ;
— information on the address ( location ) of the permanent governing body of the religious organisation at which contact with the religious organisation is to be maintained ... ”
DATE . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL stated that ( re-)registration of a religious organisation could be refused if :
“ — the aims and activities of a religious organisation contradict LAW or NORP laws – with reference to specific legal provisions ;
— the organisation has not been recognised as a religious one ;
— the articles of association or other submitted materials do not comply with NORP legislation or contain inaccurate information ;
— another religious organisation has already been registered under the same name ;
— the founder(s ) has ( have ) no capacity to act . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( as amended on DATE ) provides for the following grounds for dissolving a religious organisation by judicial decision and banning its activity :
“ — breach of public security and public order ;
— actions aimed at engaging in extremist activities ;
— coercion into destroying the family unit ;
— infringement of the personality , rights and freedoms of citizens ;

— infliction of harm , established in accordance with the law , on the morals or health of citizens , including by means of narcotic or psychoactive substances , hypnosis , or committing depraved and other disorderly acts in connection with religious activities ;
— encouragement of suicide or the refusal on religious grounds of medical assistance to persons in life- or health - threatening conditions ;
— hindrance to receiving compulsory education ;
— coercion of members and followers of a religious association and other persons into alienating their property for the benefit of the religious association ;

— hindering a citizen from leaving a religious association by threatening harm to life , health , property , if the threat can actually be carried out , or by application of force or commission of other disorderly acts ;
— inciting citizens to refuse to fulfil their civil duties established by law or to commit other disorderly acts . ”

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL § CARDINAL establishes that an application for re - registration must be refused if there are grounds for dissolving the religious organisation and banning its activity as set out in section CARDINAL § CARDINAL .
CARDINAL . Under LAW , the following rights may be exercised solely by registered religious organisations :
the right to establish and maintain religious buildings and other places of worship or pilgrimage ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) ;
the right to manufacture , acquire , export , import and distribute religious literature , printed , audio and video material and other religious articles ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) ;
the right to create cross - cultural organisations , educational institutions and mass media ( section CARDINAL LAW ) ;
the right to establish and maintain international links and contacts for pilgrimages , conferences and so on , including the right to invite foreign nationals to GPE ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) ;

the right to own buildings , plots of land , other property , financial assets and religious artefacts , including the right to have municipal and ORG property transferred to them free of charge for religious purposes and the immunity of such property from legal charge ( section QUANTITY ) ;
the right to hire employees ( section CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . In addition , the following rights are explicitly reserved to registered religious organisations , to the exclusion of other non - religious legal entities :
the right to found companies publishing religious literature or producing articles for religious services ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) ;
the right to establish licensed educational institutions for the professional training of clergy and auxiliary religious staff ( section CARDINAL § CARDINAL ) ; and
the right to invite into the NORP Federation foreign nationals planning to engage in professional religious activities , including preaching ( section DATE ) .

CARDINAL . A citizen or his or her legal representative may refuse medical assistance or require that it be terminated , save in the circumstances listed in DATE . In that case the possible consequences of such refusal should be presented in an accessible form to the citizen or his or her legal representative . The refusal must be noted in the medical record and countersigned by the citizen and a medical specialist ( LAW DATE ) .

CARDINAL . If the parents or guardians of a child below DATE of age refuse medical assistance which is necessary for saving the child 's life , the medical institution may apply to a court for the protection of the child 's interests ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Medical assistance shall be provided without the consent of the individuals concerned if they suffer from highly contagious diseases , grave mental disorders or if they have committed a criminal offence and been ordered to follow medical treatment by a judicial decision ( Article CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of GPE upheld at final instance a judgment of the lower court by which the prosecutor 's request to liquidate the local organisation of GPE 's Witnesses had been refused . CARDINAL of the grounds advanced by the prosecutor in support of the liquidation claim was that a ORG mother had refused a blood transfusion for her child . ORG noted that the mother had refused a blood transfusion but had been in favour of blood substitutes which had been successfully used during surgery . It also pointed out that the teachings of GPE 's Witnesses did not require believers to refuse blood but let everyone make an independent decision on that issue .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG in GPE upheld a decision of the lower court to hold a medical doctor liable for administering blood transfusions to an unconscious patient carrying a card stating that she was a GPE 's Witness and , as a matter of religious belief , rejected blood transfusions under any circumstances ( PERSON v. PERSON CARDINAL O.R. CARDINAL ) . It held , in particular , as follows :

“ CARDINAL ... The principles of self - determination and individual autonomy compel the conclusion that the patient may reject blood transfusions even if harmful consequences may result and even if the decision is generally regarded as foolhardy ... To transfuse a GPE 's Witness , in the face of her explicit instructions to the contrary , would , in my opinion , violate her right to control her own body and show disrespect for the religious values by which she has chosen to live her life ...

CARDINAL NORP The state undoubtedly has a strong interest in protecting and preserving the lives and health of its citizens . There clearly are circumstances where this interest may override the individual 's right to self - determination . For example , the state may , in certain cases , require that citizens submit to medical procedures in order to eliminate a health threat to the community ...

CARDINAL NORP The state 's interest in preserving the life or health of a competent patient must generally give way to the patient 's stronger interest in directing the course of her own life . As indicated earlier , there is no law prohibiting a patient from declining necessary treatment ... Recognition of the right to reject medical treatment can not , in my opinion , be said to depreciate the interest of the state in life or in the sanctity of life . Individual free choice and self - determination are themselves fundamental constituents of life . To deny individuals freedom of choice , with respect to their health care , can only lessen and not enhance the value of life ... ”
